instText: Alkenes are considered unsaturated hydrocarbons because of their double bonds.
DescriptionArray: A threadlike structure found in the nucleus of most living cells, carrying genetic information in the form of genes.
Deoxyribonucleic acid, a self-replicating material that carries individual hereditary characteristics in a cell, the main constituent of chromosomes.
The material that makes up the chromosomes of eukaryotes.
The double-layered membrane enclosing the nucleus of a cell.
Molecules that are insoluble in water and soluble in organic solvents. Include fats, oils, waxes, sterols, and triglycerides.
Protein-lined channels in the nuclear envelope which regulate the transportation of molecules between the nucleus and cytoplasm.
The viscous liquid inside a cell but outside the cell's nucleus.
The minute particles synthesized by the nucleolus, consisting of RNA and associated proteins.
A spherical granule in the nucleus, composed of protein and RNA, synthesizes ribosomes.
A membrane-bound large structure inside a living cell that controls the cell metabolism and reproduction.
The fluid within the nucleus of a eukaryotic cell surrounding the chromosomes and nucleolus.
A cell containing a membrane-bound nucleus and organelles.

description: Blood is a connective tissue that helps in the transport of hormones, respiratory gases and wastes.
heading: Hemoglobin
Plasma
Thrombocytes
Erythrocytes
Leukocytes
Granulocytes
Agranulocytes
Neutrophils
Eosinophils
Basophils
Lymphocytes
Monocytes
T-cells
B-cells
headDescription: A pigment in red blood cells that transports oxygen.
The colorless watery fluid that contains no blood cells.
Blood cells essential for blood clotting.
Blood cells that contain oxygen-carrying pigment, hemoglobin.
Also called white blood cells, these cells of immune system are involved in defending the body against diseases.
White blood cell with granules in cytoplasm.
White blood cell without granules in the cytoplasm.
A phagocyte with granules stained by neutral stains.
A leukocyte with granules that stain with eosin.
A leukocyte with granules stained by basic stains.
A type of white blood cells formed in the lymphoid tissues. It is important for the production of antibodies.
White blood cells that ingest bacteria.
A lymphocyte developed in the thymus. It regulates the immune response.
A lymphocyte that secretes immunoglobulin to inactivate antigens.
